slides.title: Network: Conventions | Periodicals | People
slides.text:
This graph displays the connections between the conventions, periodicals, and the people who both attended and edited. 

This is a view of the entire graph. Notice the broad diffusion, the low densityâ€”hardly a monolith with so many different quarters that span regions and eras.

slides.title: William Whipper
slides.text:
William Whipper attended all of the national conventions in the 1830s, the 1855 and then edited the National Reformer in 1838. 

We see the long line connecting down (scroll to follow it) from Whipper's node to the 1869 national convention in Washington DC. Remarkably, Whipper attended conventions for almost 40 years.

slides.title: 1853 Rochester National Convention
slides.text:
Perhaps no other convention sits so squarely at the center of activity of periodicals and organizing as the convention in 1853 hosted in Rochester. 

At least 8 named delegates at the 1853 convention had served as periodical editors, including Frederick Douglass, Charles B. Ray, James McCune Smith, William Cooper Nell, Stephen Myers, David Ruggles (who had actually died in 1849), William Howard Day, and David Jenkins.

slides.title: California Links
slides.text:
This section shows California's connections to the conventions and the press. 

Mifflin W. Gibbs appears at the center as a frequent attendee and newspaper editor, publisher, agent, and supporter. 

Frederick G. Barbadoes also appears among the California links for both his work on the Pacific Appeal and his attendance at most of the California conventions. Barbadoes traveled widely, including conventions in Boston (1859), Washington DC (1869) and New Orleans (1872).
